posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
I have a pile of main robot controllers from 2004 but no period correct hardware, and all of the software downloads I’ve found for a correct version of c to compile with are dead. Is this an impossible problem without finding an old pc?

Ps: I’ve looked at the information and documentation on 358’s website.

posts.name: garyk
posts.cooked:
It’d be - not impossible - to get it working but I discourage you from putting time and energy into doing so. You’d need a couple off the black cables and radio modules to get it running wirelessly. But, it calls for Gameport Joysticks you’d have to scrounge off EBay, etc. The software development environment is primitive if you could even get it to run. FRC tried getting vision to work in the 2005 game Triple Play with wood panels painted green, you can see them in the 2005 entry here: ( https://www.firstinspires.org/sites/default/files/uploads/resource_library/frc/game-and-season-info/archive/frc-game-summaries-1992-2012.pdf

As far as I know nobody got vision to work, we certainly didn’t at 972.

The CPU is hopelessly lame by today’s standards - the Floating Point (floats and doubles) math was emulated in software and is painfully slow.

I strongly encourage you to do whatever you wish to do with an Arduino and put that on your college applications instead.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: The funny thing is we have a functional 2005 vision system, and all the rest of the required hardware. I was mostly just wanting to get them working for fun. Thanks for your help!

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
It would be nifty indeed. Strongly depends on your definition of fun.

I’d imagine it would be an adventure in recreating 20-year-old development environments with a slew of virtual machines thrown in for good measure… plus a good amount of reverse engineering an IFI engineer’s thought process from 25 years ago.

Some find such things fun. But what I imagine it wouldn’t be is an education in embedded electronics - that’s a prerequisite.

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
If you really want to explore getting code compiling for the controller…

Have you looked at Kevin Watson’s FRC code repository? Kevin's FRC Code Repository

You’ll need the Microchip C18 compiler (MPLAB IDE ). https://www.microchip.com/en-us/development-tool/sw006011

posts.name: garyk
posts.cooked:
And here’s the paper I wrote, on hardware and programming techniques for the IFI system. There wasn’t this kind of thing from FIRST back then. Please get your Reefscape ‘bot working too

https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/4/0/4024994883873eac9cde4d10350faf1553275aee.pdf
